bibl.title: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, November 6, 1951

div1.p: Rath, director of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, has noted Hench's interest in preserving the structure in which the yellow fever experiments occurred. The Trust does not have funds, but would be glad to offer support and publicize his project.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, November 6, 1951
div1.opener:
National Trust for Historic Preservation
The Octagon House · Washington 6, D. C.
NEW YORK AVENUE AND 18TH STREET, N. W.
Sterling 7056
November 6, 1951
Chairman, Board of Trustees
DAVID E. FINLEY
Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees
U. S. GRANT, 3RD
GEORGE A. McANENY
Secretary
RONALD F. LEE
Treasurer
C. F. JACOBSEN

HENRY H. SURFACE Administrator
FREDERICK L. RATH, JR. Director
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
It was with great interest that we noted in the New York
Times of November 4 that you are concerned with the preservation of
the structure in which Dr. Walter Reed conducted his yellow fever ex-
periments. It occurs to us that the National Council for Historic
Sites and Buildings may be able to support this preservation project
by writing to the proper authorities in Cuba to intercede with them
to use the fund they have allocated for this purpose before the build-
ing is too far gone to be saved.

We have discussed this matter with Mrs. Laura Wood Roper,
biographer of Walter Reed, who has been interested in the program of
the National Council, and she believes that you would be able to suggest
the way in which we can be most helpful to your cause.

For your information I am enclosing information on the
National Council, and its affiliated organization, the National Trust
for Historic Preservation. We will be very glad to offer the support
of the Council to your program, and will publicize it in our next
Quarterly Report. We have 96 organizational members and many indivi-
duals throughout the country who are directly concerned in preserving
our American heritage of historic sites and buildings. Although at
this stage of our existence we do not have funds for direct financial
aid to preservation projects, we have found that the support that we
can offer to local groups and concerned individuals can prove very
effective.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Frederick L. Rath, Jr.
